chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text:
First, we have to find out the actual stock price per share which we denote with $ASP$, where the debt issue $DI$ is $1,925,000$, outstanding shares plan $1$ $OS1$ is $180,000$ and the outstanding shares plan $2$ $OS2$ is $130,000$

$$\begin{align*}
ASP&=\frac{DI}{OS1-OS2}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{1,925,000}{180,000-130,000}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{1,925,000}{50,000}\\[12pt]
&=\$38.5
\end{align*}$$

So, the actual stock price per share is $\boxed{\$38.5}$

Second, we have to find out the actual market value of plan $1$ which we denote with $AM1$, where the outstanding shares plan $1$ $OS1$ is $180,000$ and the actual stock price per share $ASP$ is $\$38.5$

$$\begin{align*}
AM1&=OS1\times ASP\\[7pt]
&=180,000\times 38.5\\[7pt]
&=6,930,000
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the  actual market value of plan $1$ is $\boxed{\$6,930,000}$

Third, we have to find out the actual market value of plan $2$ which we denote with $AM2$, where the outstanding shares plan $2$ $OS2$ is $130,000$, actual stock price per share $ASP$ is $\$38.5$ and the debt issue $DI$ is $1,925,000$

$$\begin{align*}
AM2&=OS2\times ASP+DI\\[7pt]
&=130,000\times 38.5 + 1,925,000\\[7pt]
&=5,005,000+1,925,000\\[7pt]
&=6,930,000
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the  actual market value of plan $2$ is $\boxed{\$6,930,000}$
